Modifying the spatial scale of active site has been proven a good strategy for enhancing catalytic performance. In this study, the Pd-based catalysts with different spatial scale of active site were constructed via the modification of non-metallic S or Si atoms over Pd, Cu alloyed Pd SACs, PdAg surface alloy and PdM (M=Au, Ag) IMCs catalysts, then, C2H2 semi-hydrogenation catalytic performance was identified based on DFT calculations. The findings indicate that the catalytic performance of C2H2 semi-hydrogenation is greatly influenced by the spatial extent of active site and the electronic effect modified by the S or Si atoms. Geometric effect caused by S or Si atoms reduces the spatial scale of active site over S/Pd-2 × 2, Si/Pd-3 × 3, S/Pd6Ag, S/Pd1Au1, S/Pd1Ag1 and Si/Pd1Ag1, thereby preventing green oil generation. Electronic effect caused by S or Si atoms leads to far away from the Fermi level of d-band center over S/Pd-2 × 2, Si/Pd-3 × 3, S/Pd1Au1, S/Pd1Ag1 and Si/Pd1Ag1 to improve C2H4 production activity and selectivity. Seven catalysts S/Pd-2 × 2, Si/Pd-3 × 3, PdCu-2 × 2, S/Pd6Ag, S/Pd1Au1, S/Pd1Ag1 and Si/Pd1Ag1 are screened out to present high selectivity and activity of C2H4 production, and effectively prevent green oil generation. This study provides valuable structural insights for designing high-performance catalysts by the modification of non-metallic atom in C2H2 semi-hydrogenation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pd-based catalyst Non-metallic modifier C2H2 semi-hydrogenation Catalytic performance DFT calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene (C2H4) is an important petrochemical feedstock, which is usually produced by steam cracking. There are 0.1–1 % amount of acetylene (C2H2) in the ethylene stream, and C2H2 can poison the Ziegler-Natta catalysts used for C2H4 polymerization [1,2]. Currently, the approach of semi-hydrogenation has been widely used to remove C2H2 in industry [3,4]. It is widely accepted that Pd-based catalysts perform high activity toward C2H4 generation. However, the over-hydrogenation of C2H4 easily occurs owing to its strong adsorption ability, resulting in the low C2H4 selectivity; meanwhile, the polymerization of C2 species to form oligomers (green oil) also easily occurs, which block the catalyst active site and cause catalyst deactivation [5-9]. Thus, the development of high-performance catalyst becomes an urgent thing needed to be solved, in which the excessive hydrogenation of C2 species and their coupling to produce green oil should be obviously inhibited. Doping metal is one of the most commonly used modification methods in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. Barlocco et al. [10] studied the adsorption and dissociation of H2 on the single atom alloys (SAAs) by DFT calculations and found that H2 can form the stable dihydro and dihydride complexes on the SAAs, which has high activity for hydrogenation reaction. Loffreda et al. [11] studied the selective hydrogenation of butadiene on the PdAu alloys by DFT calculations, butene adsorption on the PdAu surface with 25 at.% of Au is markedly weakened compared to that on the pure Pd(111) (by 30 %), hence enhancing the selectivity. Triggiani et al. [12] used first-principles calculations to explore the strategy of doping SrTiO3 (STO) with sodium and potassium at the Sr site, indicating that K and Na doping causes holes in the valence band of STO to obtain the required p-type electron conduction, and these holes play an important role in the electron stability of oxygen-vacancies. Bandarenka et al. [13] studied the surface and near-surface alloys of Cu/Pt(111) by electrochemical experiments and first-principles calculations, suggesting that the doping position of Cu controls the binding energy of Pt(111) with *H, *OH and *CO species, which in turn affects the catalytic performance of CO electro-oxidation. Moreover, Massaro et al. [14] studied the Mo/W doped BiVO4-based materials for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) by DFT calculations, indicating that the doping of Mo/W reorganized the surface structure of BiVO4 and formed a special Biopp site, and the stability of OER reaction intermediate at the Biopp site significantly improved the hydration and catalytic performance. The addition of the second metal to Pd is usually employed to improve C2H4 selectivity, e.g., the addition of metal Ag [15-17], Cu [18-20], Zn [21,22], etc. Glyzdova et al. [15] obtained 81 % C2H4 selectivity at 97 % C2H2 conversion by varying the molar ratio of Pd: Ag to 1: 2. Pei et al. [19] studied alkyne hydrogenation reaction on the alloyed Pd single-atom catalysts (SACs) with a Pd: Cu molar ratio of 0.006, as well as Au or Ag alloyed Pd SACs, suggesting that Pd SAC with a Pd: Cu ratio of 0.006 showed excellent C2H4 selectivity of 85 % and C2H2 conversion of 100 %. Li et al. [23] increased C2H4 selectivity from 10 % to 95 % at about 100 % C2H2 conversion by inserting a Sn phase with the Sn: Pd ratio of 0.5 to modify surface Pd ensemble and electronic structure. PdZn intermetallic compounds (IMCs) exhibit high activity and selectivity toward C2H2 semi-hydrogenation, which is attribute to the change of the adsorbed form of reaction intermediates [22]. Although Pd-based bimetallic catalysts improve C2H4 selectivity, a residual amount of green oil is inevitably generated. Huang et al. [24] studied C2H2 hydrogenation and C2 intermediate coupling over Pd and PdM (M=Au, Ag, Cu) IMCs, namely, the addition of the second metal improves C2H4 selectivity, while green oil generation cannot be inhibited. Glyzdova et al. [25] found that the increasing distance between the neighboring Pd atoms on the Zn, Ga, and Ag-doped carbon loaded Pd catalysts obviously improved C2H4 selectivity after doping with the second metal, but green oil was still generated. Above analysis shows that the second metal introduction can improve C2H4 selectivity, while it cannot effectively restrain green oil generation. Thus, how to simultaneously realize the occurrence of improving C2H4 selectivity and inhibiting green oil formation is a great challenge. Previous studies showed that the spatial scale of active site can greatly affect C2H2 semi-hydrogenation catalytic performance, in particular, the by-product green oil can be effectively inhibited [26-33]. Hyun et al. [34] found that the modified Pd catalyst with diphenyl sulfide significantly improved C2H4 selectivity without activity loss and inhibited the generation of green oil and coke, which is attributed to that the modification of diphenyl sulfide decreases the spatial scale of active site to effectively inhibit green oil generation. McKenna et al. [35-37] also found that the Pd catalysts modified by diphenyl sulfide improved C2H4 selectivity and inhibited green oil generation since the reduction of diphenyl sulfide at 393 K to S atoms occupied Pd active site, which decreased the spatial scale of active site to inhibit green oil generation. Similarly, Kim et al. [38,39] and Shin et al. [40,41] successfully reduced the amount of green oil and retarded the sintering of Pd crystals by depositing Si substances on the Pd surface since the multiple ligand adsorption sites of the catalyst were blocked. Above analysis showed that the modifier S or Si atoms on the Pd catalysts can improve the selectivity of C2H2 semi-hydrogenation and inhibit green oil generation by changing the spatial scale of active site. However, so far, on the Pd-based catalysts, whether the spatial scale of active site modified by S or Si atoms affects green oil generation, as well as the selectivity and activity in C2H2 semi-hydrogenation or not is still unknown; moreover, the difference between the modification of S and Si on the Pd-based catalysts in tuning catalytic performance of C2H2 semi-hydrogenation is still unclear. Thus, it is crucial to reveal C2H2 semi-hydrogenation mechanism and catalytic performance on the Pd-based catalysts modified by S or Si atoms. This work fully examined the hydrogenation and polymerization reactions of C2H2 on a range of Pd-based catalysts, including the Pd, Cu alloyed Pd SACs, PdAg surface alloys, and PdM IMCs (M=Au, Ag), as well as the corresponding S or Si-modified Pd-based catalysts to present different spatial scale of active site. Here, DFT calculations are employed. Pd-based catalysts with good catalytic performance for C2H2 semi-hydrogenation is screened out, and the findings are desired to present a valuable method for rationally designing and optimizing the catalyst with good catalytic performance through changing the spatial scale of active sites. 2 Computational methods and models 2.1 Computational methods All DFT calculations in this study were executed by employing the Dmol3 module within Materials Studio 8.0 [42,43]. The exchange correlation functional is characterized using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA-PBE) [44,45]. The treatment of Pd, Cu, Ag, and Au metals are carried out by the effective core potential (ECP) basis set, whereas all-electron basis set treatment is applied to the non-metal C, H, S, and Si atoms [46]. The expansion of the valence electron function is carried out by utilizing the dual numerical polarized basis set (DNP) [47,48]. The smearing width is chosen to be 0.005 Ha. The parameters for calculation convergence were as follows: the maximum force was 4.0 × 10–3 Ha·Å-1, the maximum distance was 5.0 × 10–3 Å, and the energy convergence criterion was set at 2.0 × 10–5 Ha. k-point grids of 3 × 3 × 1 and 2 × 2 × 1 was chosen for p(2 × 2) and p(3 × 3), respectively. Transition states are determined using the Complete LST/QST approach and validated through Frequency analysis and TS confirmation [49,50]. For the calculation of frequency analysis, the relaxation of catalyst surface atoms connected to the adsorbate and the full fixation of the catalyst were considered on the screened three catalysts PdCu-2 × 2, S/Pd6Ag and Si/Pd1Ag1 with excellent performance toward C2H2 selective hydrogenation, and recalculated the values of G a and ΔG of elementary reaction involved in C2H2 selective hydrogenation, it was found that the results obtained by relaxing the catalyst surface has no obvious change, which did not affect the corresponding results. On the other hand, previous studies also found that the full fixation of the catalyst is a common method used for the calculations of frequency analysis [51,52]. Based on above analysis, when calculating the frequencies, ZPEs and entropic terms, the catalyst atoms are kept fixed, and only the reactants, transition states and product molecules are relaxed. Moreover, it is believed that the current calculation method of frequency analysis and the obtained results are reliable. Extensive studies found that the higher ratio of H2: C2H2 is unfavorable for green oil generation in C2H2 semi-hydrogenation [24,53,54]. Thus, a H2: C2H2 molar ratio of 10: 1 is used, where the partial pressures of C2H4, C2H2, and H2 were 0.89, 0.01, and 0.1 atm, respectively. Over Pd-based catalysts, the temperature was done at 425 K [15,41]. 2.2 Catalyst models It is widely acknowledged that Pd catalysts exhibit significant low-temperature C2H2 conversion, yet enhancing C2H4 selectivity is challenging since the over-hydrogenation of C2H4 to ethane is easier, further, the Pd-based catalysts with highly active and selective for C2H2 semi-hydrogenation is developed, such as Pd1Cu, Pd x Ag (x = 3A, 6, 7, 8, ML) and PdM IMCs (M=Au, Ag). Such as, Qi et al. [55] studied the effect of Pd coordination number on C2H2 semi-hydrogenation catalytic performance, PdCu(111) with the coordination number of 9 had the highest C2H4 selectivity but could not inhibit green oil generation. Wang et al. [56] investigated the synergistic effects of surface composition and ensemble over PdAg surface alloy on C2H2 semi-hydrogenation catalytic performance without considering green oil generation, suggesting that Pd x Ag with surface Pd trimer had good C2H4 formation activity and selectivity. In our present study, the polymerization reaction on the Pd x Ag catalysts is further replenished (Fig. S1), and it is found that Pd x Ag catalysts is prone to green oil generation. It has been demonstrated that PdM IMCs possess high C2H4 selectivity, but they are unable to inhibit green oil generation over Pd1Ag1 and Pd1Au1, leading to the low catalyst stability [57,58]. It is worth noting that the presence of S or Si species greatly impacts green oil generation on the Pd and PdM IMCs catalysts. For example, Wu et al. [54] found that both S/Pd-2 × 2 and S/Pd-3 × 3 significantly inhibited green oil generation compared with Pd-2 × 2 and Pd-3 × 3. Wu et al. [58] also studied S-modified PdM (M=Au, Ag and Cu) IMCs, and screened out S-modified Pd1Au1 and Pd1Ag1 catalysts to present good activity and selectivity of C2H4 formation, as well as better suppressed ability toward green oil. However, the difference between the S or Si atoms modified Pd-based catalysts to tune catalytic performance is not clear. In this work, the S or Si atom is pre-adsorbed on the surface for four types of Pd-based catalysts, which include Pd, Cu alloyed Pd SACs, PdAg surface alloy, and PdM IMC (M=Au, Ag). For the Pd catalyst, the (111) crystal facet is the dominantly exposed and stable surface, so Pd(111) surfaces with four atomic layers is used to simulate Pd catalyst, where the bottom two layers kept fixed. Then, as shown in Fig. 1 , the S or Si atom is adsorbed on the p(2 × 2) or p(3 × 3) Pd catalyst to present different spatial scale of active site for Pd catalyst, which are named as S/Pd-2 × 2, Si/Pd-2 × 2, S/Pd-3 × 3 and Si/Pd-3 × 3 catalysts, respectively. Similarly, for the Cu alloyed Pd SACs, the (111) crystal facet is the dominantly exposed and stable surface of Cu catalyst, so the Cu alloyed Pd SACs is simulated by using a four-layer atomic layer of Cu(111) and substituting a surface Cu atom with a Pd atom; then, the S or Si is adsorbed on the p(2 × 2) or p(3 × 3) Cu alloyed Pd SACs to present different spatial scale of active site, named as S/PdCu-2 × 2, S/PdCu-3 × 3, Si/PdCu-2 × 2, and Si/PdCu-3 × 3 catalysts, respectively, and the bottom two layers kept fixed. Even if we are aware that bonding within the allow is metallic, i.e. delocalized, for the ease of viewing, the 9-fold coordination of surface metal atoms is represented with a ball-and-stick-model. For the PdAg surface alloy catalyst, Pd x Ag (x = 3A, 6, 7, 8, ML) is simulated by using a three atomic layer Pd (111) surface and replacing 3, 6, 7, 8 and 9 Pd atoms with Ag atoms, respectively, and the bottom one layer remain fixed. Then, the S or Si atom is adsorbed on the p(3 × 3) Pd x Ag catalysts to simulate the S/Pd x Ag and Si/Pd x Ag catalysts. For the PdM IMCs, the Pd1Ag1 and Pd1Au1 catalysts are simulated using the dominantly exposed (111) surface to construct a four atomic layers p(2 × 2) supercell with 16 surface atoms, and the bottom two layers kept fixed; the S or Si atoms initially adsorbed over Pd1Ag1 and Pd1Au1 surfaces are optimized to simulate the S or Si-modified Pd1Ag1 and Pd1Au1 IMCs catalysts, named as S/Pd1Ag1, Si/Pd1Ag1, S/Pd1Au1 and Si/Pd1Au1 catalysts, respectively. A 15 Å vacuum layer was introduced in the vertical z-direction to prevent the interactions between the slab layers. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 C2H2 semi-hydrogenation reaction mechanism As shown in Fig. 2 , C2H2 semi-hydrogenation consists of hydrogenation and polymerization processes. Three possible paths exist for the hydrogenation process: the first is C2H4 desorption path, the adsorbed C2H2(ad) is continuously hydrogenated to C2H4(ad), followed by its desorption to C2H4(g); the second is C2H4 intermediate path, the adsorbed C2H4(ad) further hydrogenates to form C2H6(ad) instead of C2H4(ad) desorption; the third is CHCH3 intermediate path, the adsorbed C2H2 (ad) is firstly hydrogenated to generate CHCH3(ad), which is subsequently hydrogenation to produce C2H6(ad). Thus, the first path for C2H4(g) generation is expected, the second and third paths toward C2H6 production should be suppressed [59-63]. Green oil is known to be the C8 C30 long-chain olefin, which is formed through its precursor 1, 3-butadiene (C4H6), namely, once the generation of 1, 3-butadiene occurs in the polymerization process, green oil generation easily occurs to cover the catalyst active site, leading to the catalyst deactivation [62,63], namely, once 1, 3-butadiene generation is suppressed, green oil generation can be inhibited. In the polymerization process, 1, 3-butadiene generation also involves three paths (Fig. 2): the first is that two C2H2(ad) couple to produce C4H4(ad), which is then easily hydrogenated to C4H6(ad); the second is the coupling of C2H2(ad) and C2H3(ad) to C4H5(ad), subsequently, C4H5(ad) is further hydrogenated to form C4H6(ad); the third is the coupling of two C2H3(ad) to form C4H6(ad) [64]. 3.2 Adsorption of the species involved in C2H2 semi-hydrogenation 3.2.1 Adsorption of S and Si atoms The most stable adsorption positions for individual S and Si atoms on the four types of Pd-based catalysts is presented in Fig. 1 and Table S1. For the Pd catalyst, the most stable adsorption position for S atom is the fcc site over Pd(111) [54], while that of Si atoms is the hcp site. For the Cu alloyed Pd SACs, the most stable adsorption position of S atoms is the fcc site consisted of Cu-Cu-Cu over PdCu-2 × 2; that on the PdCu-3 × 3 surface is the fcc site consisted of Pd-Cu-Cu. The most stable adsorption position for Si atoms is the fcc site consisted of Pd-Cu-Cu over PdCu-2 × 2 and PdCu-3 × 3. For the PdAg surface alloy catalysts, the most stable adsorption positions for S and Si atoms are the fcc site consisted of Pd-Pd-Pd site over Pd7Ag, Pd8Ag and PdMLAg, while Pd3AAg is the hcp site consisted of Pd-Pd-Pd site; Pd6Ag is the fcc consisted of Pd-Pd-Ag site. For the PdM IMC catalysts, that of S atoms adsorbed over Pd1Au1 and Pd1Ag1 are the fcc site consisted of Pd-Pd-Au and Pd-Pd-Ag, respectively [56], while the Si atom is located at the four-fold hollow site consisted of Pd-Pd-Au-Au and Pd-Pd-Ag-Ag, respectively. 3.2.2 Adsorption of H, C2Hx(x = 2–5) and C4Hx(x = 4–6) In the industrial C2H2 semi-hydrogenation reaction process, where trace amount of C2H2 need to be removed from the main C2H4, it is crucial to prioritize the adsorption of C2H2 over C2H4 on the catalyst [65-67]. According to Fig. 3 and Table S2, the adsorption strength of C2H2 markedly exceeds that of C2H4 on the Pd, Cu alloyed Pd SACs, PdAg surface alloy, and PdM IMCs, as well as the corresponding catalysts with S or Si modification. Thus, four types of Pd-based catalysts considered in the present work can meet the requirement of effective adsorption of trace C2H2. In addition, since the calculation of BSSE by Dmol3 module is not suitable for the periodic systems used in this work, and this work only want to confirm that the adsorption of C2H2 is stronger than that of C2H4 on the catalyst, namely, that is the qualitative comparison of adsorption energy between C2H2 and C2H4, as a result, the effect of BSSE on the species adsorption energy has not been considered. The stable adsorption configurations of H, C2H x (x = 2–5) and C4H x (x = 4–6) and the corresponding adsorption free energies at 425 K are shown in Fig. S2 and Table S2. 3.3 Reaction processes in C2H2 semi-hydrogenation 3.3.1 Over S or Si-modified Pd catalysts Over Si/Pd-2 × 2, as shown in Fig. 4 , the total barriers of CHCH3 intermediate and C2H4 desorption paths during the hydrogenation process are 180.2 and 139.1 kJ·mol-1, respectively. Moreover, C2H4 desorption free energy and C2H4 hydrogenation barrier are 16.9 and 67.2 kJ·mol-1, respectively. Thus, C2H4 desorption path is preferred during the hydrogenation process. The total barriers of C2H2+C2H2→C4H4, C2H2+C2H3→ C4H5 and C2H3+C2H3→C4H6 during the polymerization process are 174.5, 180.5 and 164.0 kJ·mol-1, respectively, namely, the generation of C4H6 via C2H3+C2H3 coupling path is more favorable in kinetics. Furthermore, the occurrence of C2H4 desorption path is kinetically favored than the C2H3+C2H3 coupling path. Over Si/Pd-3 × 3 (Fig. S3), C2H4 desorption path is preferred (84.1 kJ·mol-1) in the hydrogenation process. The C2H2+C2H2 coupling easily occurs (98.1 kJ·mol-1) in the polymerization process. Furthermore, C2H4 desorption path is more preferred in kinetics compared to C2H2+C2H2 coupling. Our previous work on the catalysts Pd-2 × 2, Pd-3 × 3, S/Pd-2 × 2 and S/Pd-3 × 3 [54] found that both Pd-2 × 2 and Pd-3 × 3 catalysts are preferable for the polymerization path, S/Pd-3 × 3 is preferable for over-hydrogenation path, and S/Pd-2 × 2 is favored for C2H4 desorption path. 3.3.2 Over S or Si-modified Cu alloyed Pd SACs For the Cu alloyed Pd SACs (Figs. S4∼S8), C2H4 desorption is kinetically preferred than its hydrogenation to C2H5 on the catalysts PdCu-2 × 2 (−158.5 vs. −90.7 kJ·mol-1), S/PdCu-2 × 2 (−228.7 vs. −88.7 kJ·mol-1), Si/PdCu-2 × 2 (−89.5 vs. −26.5 kJ·mol-1), PdCu-3 × 3 (−103.5 vs. −23.8 kJ·mol-1) [55], S/PdCu-3 × 3 (−100.9 vs. −55.2 kJ·mol-1) and Si/PdCu-3 × 3 (−67.8 vs. 8.9 kJ·mol-1). Meanwhile, the C2H4 desorption path exhibits greater kinetic superiority compared to the CHCH3 intermediate path on the catalysts PdCu-2 × 2 (−33.8 vs. 58.3 kJ·mol-1), Si/PdCu-2 × 2 (73.9 vs. 78.6 kJ·mol-1), PdCu-3 × 3 (33.5 vs. 103.7 kJ·mol-1) and S/PdCu-3 × 3 (26.4 vs. 67.4 kJ·mol-1), however, CHCH3 intermediate path is kinetically easier than C2H4 desorption path over S/PdCu-2 × 2 (73.0 vs. 119.4 kJ·mol-1) and Si/PdCu-3 × 3 (38.3 vs. 81.3 kJ·mol-1). Thus, in the hydrogenation process, C2H4 desorption path is preferred on the catalysts PdCu-2 × 2, Si/PdCu-2 × 2, PdCu-3 × 3 and S/PdCu-3 × 3, while C2H6 generation is favored over S/PdCu-2 × 2 and Si/PdCu-3 × 3. For the polymerization process, since the spatial scale of active sites on the catalysts PdCu-2 × 2, S/PdCu-2 × 2 and Si/PdCu-2 × 2 are all small, some polymerization paths could not occur (Fig. S9). Specifically, over PdCu-2 × 2 and S/PdCu-2 × 2, only the coupling of C2H2+C2H3 (−14.1 kJ·mol-1) and C2H3+C2H3 (47.0 kJ·mol-1) occurs, respectively. For Si/PdCu-2 × 2, C2H2+C2H2 coupling could not occurs, and C2H3+C2H3 coupling is favorable (1.8 kJ·mol-1). However, on the catalysts PdCu-3 × 3, S/PdCu-3 × 3 and Si/PdCu-3 × 3, all three paths are likely to occur. Over PdCu-3 × 3 and S/PdCu-3 × 3, C2H3+C2H3 coupling path is kinetically favorable (15.9 and 26.6 kJ·mol-1); over Si/PdCu-3 × 3, C2H2+C2H3 coupling path is kinetically superior (113.6 kJ·mol-1). Above results indicate that C2H4 desorption path is kinetically more preferred compared to the optimal coupling path on the catalysts PdCu-2 × 2 (−33.8 vs. −14.1 kJ·mol-1), S/PdCu-3 × 3 (26.4 vs. 26.6 kJ·mol-1) and Si/PdCu-3 × 3 (81.3 vs. 113.6 kJ·mol-1). However, the optimal coupling path is easier than C2H4 desorption path on the catalysts S/PdCu-2 × 2 (47.0 vs. 119.4 kJ·mol-1), Si/PdCu-2 × 2 (1.8 vs. 73.9 kJ·mol-1) and PdCu-3 × 3 (15.9 vs. 33.5 kJ·mol-1). Thus, both PdCu-2 × 2 and S/PdCu-3 × 3 catalysts are favored for C2H4 desorption path; the catalysts S/PdCu-2 × 2, Si/PdCu-2 × 2 and PdCu-3 × 3 are preferable for the polymerization path; Si/PdCu-3 × 3 is favored for the over-hydrogenation path. 3.3.3 Over S or Si-modified PdxAg catalysts For the S or Si-modified PdAg alloy catalysts (Figs. S10∼S19), C2H4 desorption easily occurs in kinetics than its hydrogenation to C2H5 on the catalysts S/Pd3AAg (−223.6 vs. −70.8 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd3AAg (−83.8 vs. 9.3 kJ·mol-1), S/Pd6Ag (−60.9 vs. −9.4 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd6Ag (−42.9 vs. 87.2 kJ·mol-1), S/Pd7Ag (−23.0 vs. 35.6 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd7Ag (−38.4 vs. 81.2 kJ·mol-1), S/Pd8Ag (−15.4 vs. 59.7 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd8Ag (−3.4 vs. 131.6 kJ·mol-1), S/PdMLAg (−1.9 vs. 53.8 kJ·mol-1), and Si/PdMLAg (−6.5 vs. 114.2 kJ·mol-1). Meanwhile, C2H4 desorption path presents a higher kinetic barrier compared to CHCH3 intermediate path over Si/Pd3AAg (100.5 vs. 34.1 kJ·mol-1) and S/Pd8Ag (107.0 vs. 106.6 kJ·mol-1), however, C2H4 desorption path is kinetically more preferred in comparison with CHCH3 intermediate path on the catalysts S/Pd3AAg (−37.1 vs. 82.1 kJ·mol-1), S/Pd6Ag (36.5 vs. 113.9 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd6Ag (111.0 vs. 168.4 kJ·mol-1), S/Pd7Ag (85.9 vs. 159.1 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd7Ag (72.5 vs. 171.8 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd8Ag (98.5 vs. 198.6 kJ·mol-1), S/PdMLAg (104.5 vs. 112.0 kJ·mol-1) and Si/PdMLAg (85.2 vs. 95.1 kJ·mol-1). Thus, in the hydrogenation process, the catalysts S/Pd3AAg, S/Pd6Ag, Si/Pd6Ag, S/Pd7Ag, Si/Pd7Ag, Si/Pd8Ag, S/PdMLAg, and Si/PdMLAg are favorable for C2H4 formation, however, both Pd3AAg and S/Pd8Ag are prone to C2H6 generation. For the polymerization process, it is found that C2H2+C2H2 coupling path is more favorable path on the catalysts S/Pd3AAg (119.4 kJ·mol-1), S/Pd7Ag (74.9 kJ·mol-1) and S/Pd8Ag (86.1 kJ·mol-1). C2H2+C2H3 coupling path easily occurs in kinetics on the catalysts Si/Pd3AAg (20.2 kJ·mol-1), S/Pd6Ag (135.4 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd7Ag (58.1 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd8Ag (82.1 kJ·mol-1) and Si/PdMLAg (50.9 kJ·mol-1). C2H3+C2H3 coupling path is preferred over Si/Pd6Ag (135.7 kJ·mol-1) and S/PdMLAg (86.4 kJ·mol-1). Above results show that the most preferred coupling path is found to be more favorable in kinetics than C2H4 desorption path on the catalysts S/Pd3AAg (119.4 vs. 128.1 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd3AAg (20.2 vs. 100.5 kJ·mol-1), S/Pd7Ag (74.9 vs. 85.9 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd7Ag (58.1 vs. 72.5 kJ·mol-1), S/Pd8Ag (86.1 vs. 107.0 kJ·mol-1), Si/Pd8Ag (82.1 vs. 98.5 kJ·mol-1), S/PdMLAg (86.4 vs. 104.5 kJ·mol-1) and Si/PdMLAg (50.9 vs. 85.2 kJ·mol-1). However, the most preferred coupling path is greatly difficult to occur in comparison with C2H4 desorption path over S/Pd6Ag (135.4 vs. 36.5 kJ·mol-1) and Si/Pd6Ag (135.7 vs. 111.0 kJ·mol-1). Thus, the catalysts S/Pd3AAg, Si/Pd3AAg, S/Pd7Ag, Si/Pd7Ag, S/Pd8Ag, Si/Pd8Ag, S/PdMLAg and Si/PdMLAg are preferable for the polymerization path; both S/Pd6Ag and Si/Pd6Ag are favored for C2H4 desorption path. 3.3.4 Over S or Si-modified PdM IMCs catalysts For the Si-modified Pd1Au1 and Pd1Ag1 catalysts (Figs. S20, S21), in the hydrogenation process, C2H4 desorption is more preferable in kinetics than its hydrogenation over Si/Pd1Au1 (−98.9 vs. −43.2 kJ·mol-1) and Si/Pd1Ag1 (−57.2 vs. 14.4 kJ·mol-1), moreover, C2H4 desorption path kinetically preferred to occur than CHCH3 intermediate path over Si/Pd1Au1 (58.6 vs. 95.6 kJ·mol-1) and Si/Pd1Ag1 (51.2 vs. 218.4 kJ·mol-1). In the polymerization process, C2H2+C2H2 coupling path is kinetically easier over Si/Pd1Au1 (186.8 kJ·mol-1) and Si/Pd1Ag1 (212.6 kJ·mol-1). Furthermore, compared with the most preferred coupling path, C2H4 desorption path is more favorable to occur over Si/Pd1Au1 (92.2 vs. 186.8 kJ·mol-1) and Si/Pd1Ag1 (84.0 vs. 212.6 kJ·mol-1). For the S-modified Pd1Au1 and Pd1Ag1 catalysts, our previous work has investigated PdM IMCs [57] and S-modified PdM IMCs [58], indicating that the Pd1Ag1 and Pd1Au1 catalysts are preferable for the polymerization path, while both S/Pd1Ag1 and S/Pd1Au1 are preferable for C2H4 desorption path. Above results show that both Pd1Ag1 and Pd1Au1 catalysts are preferable for the polymerization path, the catalysts S/Pd1Ag1, S/Pd1Au1, Si/Pd1Ag1 and Si/Pd1Au1 are preferable for C2H4 desorption path. 3.4 General discussion 3.4.1 The selectivity, activity, and stability of catalysts During the hydrogenation process, C2H4 production activity is indicated by the rate of C2H4 generation obtained by using a two-step method [68–72] (the details can be found in the Supplementary Material). Meanwhile, when the occurrence of CHCH3 intermediate path is more difficult than C2H4 desorption path, C2H4 selectivity can be quantified in terms of energy difference between C2H4 hydrogenation to C2H5 and C2H4 desorption [54-58,68,69], which is defined as follows. G sel , C 2 H 4 = G a ( C 2 H 4 ) − G des ( C 2 H 4 ) Where G a(C2H4) denotes the activation free energy required for the hydrogenation of C2H4 to produce C2H5; G des(C2H4) denotes the desorption free energy of C2H4. Moreover, a higher positive value of G sel,C2H4 indicates a greater selectivity toward C2H4. It is worth noting that green oil will cover active site, leading to the catalyst deactivation, namely, the catalyst stability is closely related to green oil generation, so the catalyst stability is assessed by measuring 1, 3-butadiene selectivity [73], and the higher selectivity means the easier green oil production. When the C2H2+C2H2 coupling path is the optimal path for the polymerization process, the selectivity of 1, 3-butadiene is evaluated by the total energy barrier difference between the C2H2+C2H2 coupling path and C2H4 desorption path. When the C2H2+C2H3 or C2H3+C2H3 coupling path is the optimal path, the 1, 3-butadiene selectivity is evaluated by the total energy barrier difference between C2H3+H→C2H4 and the optimal coupling path C2H2+C2H3→C4H5 or C2H3+C2H3→C4H6. As listed in Table 1 and Fig. 5 , for Pd catalyst, C2H4 selectivity (kJ·mol-1) is S/Pd-2 × 2 (101.5)>Si/Pd-2 × 2 (50.3)>Si/Pd-3 × 3 (40.0)>S/Pd-3 × 3 (−1.7)>Pd-3 × 3 (−7.7)> Pd-2 × 2 (−17.2). C2H4 production activity (s-1·site-1) is S/Pd-2 × 2 (2.75 × 106)>Si/Pd-3 × 3 (4.08 × 102)>S/Pd-3 × 3 (1.80 × 101)>Pd-2 × 2 (1.11 × 10°)>Pd-3 × 3 (6.27 × 10–2)>Si/Pd-2 × 2 (7.09 × 10–5). 1, 3-butadiene selectivity (kJ·mol-1) is S/Pd-2 × 2 (−60.0)<Si/Pd-2 × 2 (−46.4)<S/Pd-3 × 3 (−15.7)<Si/Pd-3 × 3 (−14.0)<Pd-2 × 2 (31.1)<Pd-3 × 3 (35.7). Thus, the S/Pd-2 × 2 and Si/Pd-3 × 3 catalysts are screened out to exhibit high C2H4 selectivity and production activity, moreover, these two catalysts can also prevent green oil generation. For Cu alloyed Pd SACs (Table 1 and Fig. S22), C2H4 selectivity (kJ·mol-1) is PdCu-3 × 3 (79.7)>PdCu-2 × 2 (67.8)>Si/PdCu-2 × 2 (63.0)>S/PdCu-3 × 3 (45.7)> Si/PdCu-3 × 3 (−43.0)>S/PdCu-2 × 2 (−46.4). The activity (s-1·site-1) is PdCu-2 × 2 (3.25 × 105)>S/PdCu-3 × 3 (1.95 × 102)>PdCu-3 × 3 (3.51 × 10°)>Si/PdCu-2 × 2 (4.21 × 10–1)> Si/PdCu-3 × 3 (1.64 × 10–3)>S/PdCu-2 × 2 (5.27 × 10–12). 1, 3-butadiene selectivity (kJ·mol-1) is Si/PdCu-3 × 3 (−32.3)<PdCu-2 × 2 (−19.7)<S/PdCu-3 × 3 (−0.2)<PdCu-3 × 3 (17.6)< Si/PdCu-2 × 2 (72.1)<S/PdCu-2 × 2 (72.4). Thus, the PdCu-2 × 2 catalyst has been obtained to exhibit high C2H4 selectivity and production activity, and this catalyst can also prevent green oil generation. For PdAg surface alloy catalysts (Table 1 and Fig. S23), C2H4 selectivity (kJ·mol-1) is S/Pd3AAg (152.8)>Si/Pd8Ag (135.0)>Si/Pd6Ag (130.1)>Si/PdMLAg (120.7)> Si/Pd7Ag (119.6)>S/Pd7Ag (58.6)>S/PdMLAg (55.7)>S/Pd6Ag (51.5)> S/Pd8Ag (−0.4)> Si/Pd3AAg (−66.4). The activity (s-1·site-1) is S/Pd6Ag (6.05 × 105)>Si/PdMLAg (2.99 × 102)>S/Pd7Ag (2.45 × 102)>Si/Pd7Ag (2.25 × 102)>Si/Pd8Ag (5.07 × 10°)> Si/Pd3AAg (1.78 × 10°)>S/PdMLAg (1.27 × 10°)>S/Pd8Ag (6.25 × 10–1)>Si/Pd6Ag (1.52 × 10–4)>S/Pd3AAg (1.90 × 10–12). 1, 3-butadiene selectivity (kJ·mol-1) is S/Pd6Ag (−98.9)<Si/Pd6Ag (−24.7)<S/Pd3AAg (8.7)<S/Pd7Ag (11.0)<Si/Pd7Ag (14.4)< Si/Pd8Ag (16.4)<S/PdMLAg (18.1)<S/Pd8Ag (20.9)<Si/PdMLAg (34.3)<Si/Pd3AAg (80.3). Thus, the catalyst S/Pd6Ag is obtained to possess high C2H4 selectivity and production activity, and this catalyst can also prevent green oil generation. For PdM IMCs (Table 1 and Fig. S24), C2H4 selectivity (kJ·mol-1) is Si/Pd1Ag1 (71.6)>S/Pd1Ag1 (58.2)>Si/Pd1Au1 (55.7)>S/Pd1Au1 (50.8)>Pd1Ag1 (44.1)>Pd1Au1 (36.0); the activity (s-1·site-1) is S/Pd1Au1 (4.87 × 104)>Pd1Au1 (3.01 × 104)>S/Pd1Ag1 (5.06 × 103)>Si/Pd1Ag1 (4.20 × 102)>Si/Pd1Au1 (4.12 × 101)>Pd1Ag1 (4.41 × 10°); 1, 3-butadiene selectivity (kJ·mol-1) is Si/Pd1Ag1 (−128.6)<S/Pd1Ag1 (−113.9)<Si/Pd1Au1 (−94.6)<S/Pd1Au1 (−84.4)<Pd1Au1 (20.8)<Pd1Ag1 (22.6). Thus, three catalysts Si/Pd1Ag1, S/Pd1Ag1 and S/Pd1Au1 have been screened out, which exhibit high C2H4 selectivity and production activity, as well as better prevention ability of green oil generation. 3.4.2 Influence of adsorbed S or Si atom on H2 dissociation Since H2 dissociation also plays a key role in C2H2 semi-hydrogenation, H2 adsorption and dissociation were further investigated over four types of Pd-based catalysts. Fig. S25a presents the initial and optimized structures of H2 adsorption over 11 catalysts Si/Pd-2 × 2, Si/Pd-3 × 3, Si/PdCu-2 × 2, S/Pd6Ag, S/Pd7Ag, S/Pd8Ag, S/PdMLAg, Si/Pd6Ag, Si/Pd7Ag, Si/Pd8Ag and Si/PdMLAg, the results show that H2 dissociates spontaneously to provide enough hydrogen atoms for the hydrogenation reaction. Meanwhile, Fig. S25b presents the dissociation of molecular adsorption H2 on the remaining 8 catalysts, the activation free energies of H2 dissociation on the PdCu-2 × 2, S/PdCu-2 × 2, S/PdCu-3 × 3, Si/PdCu-3 × 3, S/Pd3AAg, Si/Pd3AAg, Si/Pd1Ag1 and Si/Pd1Au1 are 22.1, 21.8, 31.2, 6.2, 16.6, 99.4, 22.6 and 38.5 kJ/mol, respectively. Compared with the hydrogenation process, H2 dissociation is more favorable in kinetics than C2H2 hydrogenation to C2H4. Above results show that the sufficient hydrogen sources can be provided for the semi-hydrogenation of C2H2 over all considered Pd-based catalyst, and H2 dissociation is not the rate-determined step. 3.4.3 Geometric effect and the difference between S and Si modification For Pd catalysts, as shown in Fig. 6 a, compared to Pd-2 × 2 catalyst (5.502 Å and −104.3 kJ·mol-1), the S or Si-modified Pd-2 × 2 catalyst decreases the spatial scale of Pd active site (2.691 and 2.711 Å), which changes the adsorption form of C2H4 from the Pd-Pd bridge site to away from the catalyst surface over S/Pd-2 × 2 [54] and the Pd-Si bridge site over Si/Pd-2 × 2 (Fig. S2), and greatly reduces the adsorption energy of C2H4 (−17.3 and −16.9 kJ·mol-1) to facilitate C2H4 desorption. Meanwhile, the preferred polymerization path is C2H3+C2H3 coupling path over Pd-2 × 2, while over S/Pd-2 × 2, the decreased spatial scale of active site cannot satisfy the co-adsorption of two C2H3 species, resulting in the difficult occurrence of green oil generation. However, the distance between two co-adsorbed C2H3 species increases over Si/Pd-2 × 2 (2.929 vs. 2.777 Å) (Fig. S27), which increases the barrier of the polymerization reaction. Over Pd-3 × 3 catalyst (8.253 Å), the spatial scale of Pd active site decreases over S/Pd-3 × 3 and Si/Pd-3 × 3 (5.404 and 5.458 Å), while it has nearly negligible impacts on C2H4 adsorption form. Meanwhile, the preferred polymerization path is C2H2+C2H3 coupling path over Pd-3 × 3, while over S/Pd-3 × 3 and Si/Pd-3 × 3, the decreased spatial scale of active site leads to the increasing distance between two co-adsorbed C2 species over S/Pd-3 × 3 and Si/Pd-3 × 3 compared to that over Pd-3 × 3 (3.866 and 3.861 vs. 2.816 Å), increasing the energy barrier of polymerization reaction to prevent green oil. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 6b, when the spatial scale of active site over Pd, as well as S or Si-modified Pd catalysts increases, the selectivity of green oil also gradually increases, indicating that the smaller spatial scale of active site over Pd catalyst is more conducive to preventing green oil generation. For Cu alloyed Pd SACs, compared to PdCu SACs, both S and Si modifications reduced the spatial scale of active site over PdCu-2 × 2 (5.112 vs. 2.492 and 2.518 Å) and PdCu-3 × 3 (7.668 vs. 4.998 and 5.032 Å) (Fig. S28a). Over PdCu-2 × 2 catalyst, Si modification changed the adsorption site of C2H4 from the top Pd to the top Si, which increased C2H4 adsorption energy of (−28.6 vs. −0.4 kJ·mol-1), leading to the difficult C2H4 desorption. However, the reduced spatial scale of active site has nearly negligible impacts on C2H4 adsorption form over S/PdCu-2 × 2. Similarly, the same situation also occurs over PdCu-3 × 3. Over PdCu-2 × 2, the preferred polymerization path is C2H2+C2H3 coupling path, while the decreased spatial scale of active site does not accommodate the co-adsorption of C2H2 and C2H3 species over S/PdCu-2 × 2; meanwhile, the increasing distance between two co-adsorbed C2 species over Si/PdCu-2 × 2 compared to PdCu-2 × 2 (3.435 vs. 2.730 Å) (Fig. S29) also increases the activation barrier of the polymerization reaction to prevent green oil generation. Over PdCu-3 × 3 catalyst, the preferred polymerization path is C2H3+C2H3 coupling path, the decreased spatial scale of active site leads to the increasing distance between two co-adsorbed C2H3 species over S/PdCu-3 × 3 and Si/PdCu-3 × 3 compared with PdCu-3 × 3 (2.988 and 3.021 vs. 2.889 Å) (Fig. S29), which prevent green oil generation. Furthermore, the selectivity of green oil shows an inverted volcanic curve relationship with the spatial scale of active site (Fig. S28b), and the suitable spatial scale of active site is the range of 4.9∼5.2 Å. For PdAg surface alloy catalysts, over Pd3AAg catalyst, Si modification changed the position where the reaction occurs from the top Pd to the top Si, S modification changed that from the top Pd to the top Ag. The same situation also occurs on the Pd6Ag. Meanwhile, the optimal polymerization path over Pd6Ag is C2H2+C2H3 coupling path, the increased distance between the co-adsorbed C2H2 and C2H3 species over S/Pd6Ag and Si/Pd6Ag compared with that over Pd6Ag (4.702 and 4.257 vs. 2.655 Å) (Fig. S29) effectively prevent green oil generation. On the Pd7Ag, Pd8Ag and PdMLAg catalysts, the geometric effect caused by S or Si are almost negligible. For PdM IMCs catalysts, over Pd1Au1 catalyst, the optimal path is C2H3+C2H3 coupling path, since S or Si modification reduces the spatial scale of active site, the distances between two co-adsorbed C2H3 species increased over S/Pd1Au1 (4.182 vs. 3.029 Å) and Si/Pd1Au1 (6.463 vs. 3.029 Å) (Fig. S30), as a result, both S and Si modifications could significantly prevent green oil generation. The same situation also occurs on the Pd1Ag1 catalyst. Above results show that the S and Si modification can reduce the spatial scale of active sites on these four types of Pd-based catalysts. For the same catalyst, the spatial scale of active site modified by S is slightly smaller than that by Si modification. When few Pd active sites exist on the catalyst surface, such as the catalysts Pd-2 × 2, PdCu-2 × 2, PdCu-3 × 3, Pd3AAg and Pd6Ag, Si modification changed the active site where the reaction occurs from the top Pd to the top Si (Fig. S2), namely, the occurrence of C2H2 semi-hydrogenation reactions compete between the Si and Pd active sites. However, for S modification, the reaction still occurs at the unoccupied Pd or Ag active site. 3.4.4 Electronic effects and the difference between S and Si modification Numerous studies showed that the d-band center can affect the adsorption strength of reactive species to alter the reactivity [54-58]; meanwhile, the further d-band center away from the Fermi level means the weaker adsorption strength of reactive species [74,75], so the electronic effect is further investigated. For Pd catalysts, see Fig. 7 a, for Pd-2 × 2 catalyst, the d-band center of surface Pd atoms on the catalysts Pd-2 × 2, S/Pd-2 × 2 and Si/Pd-2 × 2 is −1.82, −2.30 and −2.20 eV, respectively, namely, the d-band center of S/Pd-2 × 2 and Si/Pd-2 × 2 is higher by 0.48 and 0.38 eV than that of Pd-2 × 2, which decreases C2H4 adsorption energy and improves C2H4 selectivity (Fig. 7b); only S modification improve C2H4 production activity, while Si modification greatly reduced C2H4 production activity. Over Pd-3 × 3 catalyst, S or Si modification cause its d-band center away from Fermi level to decrease C2H4 adsorption strength, improving C2H4 selectivity and production activity. Thus, the electronic properties caused by S or Si modification have similar effects over Pd-3 × 3, while that caused by S atoms are much larger than that caused by Si atoms over Pd-2 × 2. For Cu alloyed Pd SACs, the d-band center of surface metal atoms is −2.22, −2.57, −2.79, −2.54, −2.5, and −2.62 eV on the catalysts PdCu-2 × 2, S/PdCu-2 × 2, Si/PdCu-2 × 2, PdCu-3 × 3, S/PdCu-3 × 3 and Si/PdCu-3 × 3, respectively (Fig. S31). Over PdCu-2 × 2, the d-band center of S/PdCu-2 × 2 and Si/PdCu-2 × 2 is higher by 0.35 and 0.57 eV than that of PdCu-2 × 2, which decreases C2H4 production activity (Fig. S32). Similarly, over PdCu-3 × 3 catalyst, the d-band center for Si/PdCu-3 × 3 is higher by 0.08 eV than PdCu-3 × 3, which decrease C2H4 production activity, while the d-band center for S/PdCu-3 × 3 is lower by 0.04 eV than that for PdCu-3 × 3, which increases C2H4 production activity. Thus, the electronic properties caused by S or Si modification have similar effects on the Pd-2 × 2, while that caused by S atoms are much larger than that caused by Si atoms on the Pd-3 × 3. For PdAg surface alloy catalysts, on the catalysts Pd3AAg, S/Pd3AAg, Si/Pd3AAg, Pd6Ag, S/Pd6Ag, Si/Pd6Ag, Pd7Ag, S/Pd7Ag, Si/Pd7Ag, Pd8Ag, S/Pd8Ag, Si/Pd8Ag, PdMLAg, S/PdMLAg and Si/PdMLAg, the d-band centers of metal surface are −3.07, −3.17, −3.23, −2.29, −2.38, −2.52, −1.99, −2.25, −2.33, −1.73, −2.02, −2.07, −1.5, −1.79, and −1.8 eV, respectively (Fig. S33). Compared to the unmodified catalysts, the d-band centers of the catalysts modified by S or Si are all far away from the Fermi level, which decreases C2H4 adsorption energy to facilitate C2H4 desorption. According to Fig. S34, the d-band center for S/Pd3AAg and Si/Pd3AAg is 0.1 and 0.16 eV higher than that for Pd3AAg, but C2H4 production activity decreases sharply; the d-band center for S/Pd6Ag and Si/Pd6Ag is 0.09 and 0.23 eV higher than that for Pd6Ag, and the electronic effect of S slightly enhances C2H4 production activity over S/Pd6Ag, while Si/Pd6Ag has lower C2H4 production activity. The d-band center of S/PdMLAg and Si/PdMLAg is 0.29 and 0.30 eV higher than that of PdMLAg, and the electronic effects induced by S and Si increase C2H4 production activity; while on the remaining catalysts, the S and Si modification have little effect on C2H4 production activity. Thus, the electronic properties of Pd3AAg, Pd7Ag, Pd8Ag and PdMLAg catalysts caused by S or Si modification have similar effects, while that caused by S atoms are larger than that caused by Si atoms on the Pd6Ag. For PdM IMC catalysts, on the catalysts Pd1Au1, S/Pd1Au1, Si/Pd1Au1, Pd1Ag1, S/Pd1Ag1 and Si/Pd1Ag1, the d-band centers of surface metal are −2.39, −2.47, −2.81, −2.53, −2.63, and −2.93 eV, respectively (Fig. S35). Over Pd1Ag1 catalyst, the d-band center for S/Pd1Ag1 and Si/Pd1Ag1 is higher by 0.1 and 0.4 eV than that for Pd1Ag1, which decreases C2H4 adsorption energy to effectively enhance C2H4 selectivity and production activity over S/Pd1Ag1 and Si/Pd1Ag1 (Fig. S36). Similarly, on the Pd1Au1 catalyst, the d-band center for S/Pd1Au1 and Si/Pd1Au1 is higher by 0.08 and 0.42 eV than that for Pd1Au1, which decreases C2H4 adsorption energy to enhance C2H4 selectivity, while only S/Pd1Au1 enhances C2H4 production activity. Thus, the electronic properties of Pd1Ag1 caused by S or Si modification have similar effects, while that caused by S atoms are much larger than that caused by Si atoms on the Pd1Au1. Above studies show that over four types of Pd-based catalysts, the electronic properties induced by S or Si modification have similar effects on the partial catalysts, then, on the remaining catalysts, the effects of electronic properties modified by S atom is much greater than that modified by Si atom. 4 Conclusions This work fully investigated catalytic performance of C2H2 semi-hydrogenation on the catalysts Pd, Cu alloyed Pd SACs, PdAg surface alloy and PdM IMCs, as well as the corresponding catalysts modified by S or Si atoms using DFT calculations, aiming at revealing the microscopic roles of S and Si atoms and the difference between S and Si atom modification. The results show that the modification of S and Si atoms obviously the geometrical and electronic effects of Pd-based catalysts, and the difference between S and Si atom modification is obvious. For the Pd catalysts, the geometrical effect induced by S or Si atoms improves C2H4 selectivity and prevents green oil, and the electronic effect is conducive to improving C2H4 selectivity and production activity. For the Cu alloyed Pd SACs, the modification of S and Si are not conducive to improving catalytic performance. For the PdAg surface alloy catalysts, the synergistic geometrical and electronic effects induced by S atoms on the S/Pd6Ag enhanced C2H4 production activity and selectivity, and enormously prevent green oil. For the PdM IMCs, both S/Pd1Au1 and S/Pd1Ag1 is similar with S/Pd6Ag; the Si modification increase C2H4 selectivity and prevent green oil on the Si/Pd1Au1 and Si/Pd1Ag1, however, it has smaller effect on C2H4 production activity. Overall, electronic effect induced by S atoms is stronger than that by Si atoms, while geometrical effect induced by Si atoms is stronger than that of S atoms. This work provides valuable theoretical foundation and structure information for rationally designing high-performance catalysts modified by non-metal atom on the catalyst surface. coredata.dc:description: Modifying the spatial scale of active site has been proven a good strategy for enhancing catalytic performance. In this study, the Pd-based catalysts with different spatial scale of active site were constructed via the modification of non-metallic S or Si atoms over Pd, Cu alloyed Pd SACs, PdAg surface alloy and PdM (M=Au, Ag) IMCs catalysts, then, C2H2 semi-hydrogenation catalytic performance was identified based on DFT calculations. The findings indicate that the catalytic performance of C2H2 semi-hydrogenation is greatly influenced by the spatial extent of active site and the electronic effect modified by the S or Si atoms. Geometric effect caused by S or Si atoms reduces the spatial scale of active site over S/Pd-2 × 2, Si/Pd-3 × 3, S/Pd6Ag, S/Pd1Au1, S/Pd1Ag1 and Si/Pd1Ag1, thereby preventing green oil generation. Electronic effect caused by S or Si atoms leads to far away from the Fermi level of d-band center over S/Pd-2 × 2, Si/Pd-3 × 3, S/Pd1Au1, S/Pd1Ag1 and Si/Pd1Ag1 to improve C2H4 production activity and selectivity. Seven catalysts S/Pd-2 × 2, Si/Pd-3 × 3, PdCu-2 × 2, S/Pd6Ag, S/Pd1Au1, S/Pd1Ag1 and Si/Pd1Ag1 are screened out to present high selectivity and activity of C2H4 production, and effectively prevent green oil generation. This study provides valuable structural insights for designing high-performance catalysts by the modification of non-metallic atom in C2H2 semi-hydrogenation.
